definition: An organism's complete set of DNA.
example_or_note: Includes all genes and noncoding sequences.

definition: A DNA region that codes for a functional RNA or protein.
example_or_note: Often corresponds to ORFs in bacteria.

definition: A continuous stretch of codons that may encode a protein.
example_or_note: Starts with ATG in many bacteria.

definition: A DNA sequence that initiates transcription.
example_or_note: Recognized by RNA polymerase sigma factors.

definition: A functional unit of DNA containing multiple genes under one promoter.
A three-nucleotide sequence specifying an amino acid.
A tRNA sequence complementary to a codon.
The codon that initiates translation.
A codon that terminates translation.
A sequence where ribosomes bind to start translation.
A ribosome binding site upstream of start codons.
The untranslated region upstream of the coding sequence.
The untranslated region downstream of the coding sequence.
The full set of RNA transcripts produced by a genome.
The entire set of proteins expressed by a cell.
Chemical modifications to DNA that regulate gene expression.
Addition of a methyl group to DNA or proteins.
The process of copying the DNA molecule.
A region where DNA replication begins.
A site where replication forks meet and terminate.
An enzyme that unwinds DNA strands.
An enzyme that synthesizes DNA or RNA.
An enzyme that joins DNA fragments.
An enzyme that manages DNA supercoiling.
Twisting of DNA that affects compaction and gene expression.
The primary DNA molecule containing the genome.
example_or_note: Bacteria usually have one circular chromosome.

definition: A small, circular DNA molecule independent of the chromosome.
Horizontal gene transfer via cell-to-cell contact.
Uptake of naked DNA from the environment.
Gene transfer mediated by bacteriophages.
A short mobile DNA element encoding only transposase.
A mobile DNA element with additional genes (e.g., AMR genes).
A transposon formed by two IS elements flanking a gene.
A genetic platform that captures gene cassettes.
A mobile gene unit flanked by recombination sites.
A bacterial immune system against phages.
Short sequences derived from phages in CRISPR arrays.
Proteins associated with CRISPR immune function.
A virus that infects bacteria.
A phage genome integrated into the host chromosome.
A phage lifecycle where DNA is integrated into the host genome.
A phage lifecycle that results in host lysis.
The genetic makeup of an organism.
Observable characteristics of an organism.
Different versions of a gene.
A single nucleotide polymorphism in the genome.
Insertion or deletion of bases in DNA.
Large genomic changes such as inversions or duplications.
Reconstruction of the genome sequence from reads.
A contiguous sequence assembled from overlapping reads.
A series of contigs linked into a longer sequence.
The average number of reads covering each base.
A short sequence obtained from a sequencer.
A sequencing read typically 50–300 bp.
A sequencing read often >10 kbp.
High-throughput DNA sequencing technologies.
The order of nucleotides in DNA or RNA.
A file format storing reads and quality scores.
A file format storing nucleotide or protein sequences.
A metric indicating base-calling accuracy.
Short sequences added during library prep.
Preparing DNA fragments for sequencing.
Adding unique tags to identify samples.
Sequencing multiple samples in one run.
Converting raw signals into nucleotide sequences.
A graph representing overlaps between reads.
Assembly without using a reference genome.
Aligning reads to a known reference genome.
Detecting SNPs, indels, or structural variants.
The full complement of genes in a species.
Genes shared by all strains of a species.
Genes present in only some strains.
A gene encoding antimicrobial resistance.
Genes that degrade β-lactam antibiotics.
Sequence typing based on housekeeping genes.
A group of related sequence types.
example_or_note: CC2 is a major A. baumannii lineage.

definition: A DNA sequence occurring multiple times.
A segment of DNA that is reversed.
A segment of DNA copied within the genome.
Loss of a genomic region.
Movement of genes between organisms.
A large horizontally acquired genomic region.
A genomic island associated with virulence.
A genomic island carrying AMR genes.
Genetic units capable of moving within or between genomes.
A system protecting bacteria from foreign DNA.
A multi-subunit restriction–modification complex.
A restriction enzyme + methylase pair.
A complex requiring two sites for cleavage.
The application of computational tools to biological data.
Arranging sequences to identify similarity.
Similarity due to shared ancestry.
Evolutionary relationships among organisms.
A branching diagram showing evolutionary relationships.
A sequence representing the most common base at each position.
Uneven read depth across regions.
Percentage of G and C bases in DNA.
A sequence fragment of length k.
Removing low-quality or adapter bases from reads.
Aligning reads to a reference genome.
A binary format for storing alignments.
A text format for alignments.
A file for variant calls such as SNPs and indels.
Identifying genes and features within a genome.
A gene-like sequence that has lost function.
DNA sequences controlling gene expression.
A DNA region where repressors bind.
A sequence causing transcription termination via hairpin formation.
A termination mechanism requiring Rho factor.
Multiple mutations combining to alter phenotype.
Mutations that reduce fitness cost of resistance.
The growth disadvantage caused by certain mutations.
example_or_note: May be eliminated by compensatory evolution.

definition: A high mutation rate due to defects in repair genes.
A dramatically elevated mutation rate.
A portable nanopore sequencer developed by Oxford Nanopore Technologies.
example_or_note: Generates long reads suitable for de novo assembly.

definition: A method to amplify specific DNA sequences in vitro.
example_or_note: Requires primers, polymerase, and thermal cycling.

definition: A small non-coding RNA that regulates gene expression post-transcriptionally.
example_or_note: Usually 20–24 nt and binds to target mRNAs.

definition: RNA that carries genetic information from DNA to the ribosome.
A small interfering RNA that directs sequence-specific mRNA degradation.
A transfer RNA that brings amino acids to the ribosome during translation.
A coding segment of a gene that remains in mature mRNA after splicing.
A non-coding region removed during RNA splicing.
A gene defined by its ability to complement mutations in cis/trans tests.
example_or_note: Nearly equivalent to 'gene' in modern usage.

definition: An mRNA that encodes only one protein.
An mRNA that encodes multiple proteins in a single transcript.
The process of removing introns from pre-mRNA to form mature mRNA.
example_or_note: Mediated by the spliceosome in eukaryotes.

definition: A first-generation DNA sequencing method based on chain-terminating dideoxynucleotides.
example_or_note: Gold standard for validating mutations and small variants.

definition: An isothermal nucleic acid amplification method performed at a constant temperature.
example_or_note: Useful for point-of-care testing and rapid pathogen detection.

definition: An isothermal amplification technique that amplifies RNA targets using reverse transcriptase and RNA polymerase.
example_or_note: Used in high-sensitivity diagnostic assays such as STI testing.

definition: A molecular typing method that differentiates strains based on PCR amplification patterns of ORFs.
example_or_note: Applied in Acinetobacter and Enterobacteriaceae epidemiology.

definition: A structural and functional RNA component of ribosomes essential for protein synthesis.
example_or_note: Includes 16S rRNA (bacterial small subunit marker) and 23S rRNA; widely used for bacterial identification.

definition: A non-coding DNA region between genes.
example_or_note: Often used for strain-level typing such as 16S–23S rRNA IGS analysis.

definition: A DNA region located between two genes and typically non-coding.
example_or_note: May contain promoters, terminators, or regulatory sequences.

definition: A non-coding region between rRNA genes transcribed as a single unit and later processed.
example_or_note: ITS1 and ITS2 are widely used for fungal identification and phylogenetics.
